string-array.name: quiz_array
string-array.item: Once she was abducted by Zeus,\n and now on her flag twelve stars: Europe
This planet is nearest the sun: Mercury
The lightest existing metal: Aluminium
This Italian artist painted the Birth of Venus: Botticelli
In this city you can see\n Michelangelo’s David: Florence
This country once was called Rhodesia: Zimbabwe
On this island Napoleon was born: Corsica
Another name for the study of fossils: Paleontology
This cheese is traditionally used for pizzas: Mozzarella
This beer is marketed as The king of beers: Budweiser
He was Mozart's great rival: Salieri
This country had a Prime Minister\n and President who were twin brothers: Poland
Name of the German airline: Lufthansa
The most famous university of Paris: Sorbonne
It is both a French wine region\n and a luxury American automobile: Cadillac
This country is named after Venice: Venezuela
He killed the Minotaur: Theseus
She was the imaginary love of Don Quixote: Dulcinea
He said \"I think therefore I am\": Descartes
Posture in yoga: Asana
This species of ape has a natural\n copper tinge to its hair or fur: Orangutan
Tarzan's main item of clothing: Loincloth
Pigs are used to sniff out this delicacy: Truffle
A word that can be spelt the same\n both backwards and forwards: Palindrome
This gas is most predominant in the sun: Hydrogen
He was the first to say\n that the earth orbited the sun: Copernicus
He designed a labyrinth for King Minos: Daedalus
This festival commemorates\n the visit of the Magi to Jesus: Epiphany
On this animal you'll find a howdah: Elephant
Horse’s name on which the Odin rode: Sleipnir
The smallest breed of dog: Chihuahua
What kind of animal is a gribble?: Crustacean
A venomous snake that lives in Japan: Mamushi
An assembly of owls is referred to as a: Parliament
The name for a two-humped camel: Bactrian
When you have more fingers\n than you should: Polydactyly
This animal is the symbol\n of the motor manufacturer Suzuki: Rhinoceros
The name of the highest mountain in Africa: Kilimanjaro
This country is popularly knowns\n as ‘land of the windmills’: Netherlands
A person able to use both hands\n with equal skill: Ambidextrous
A reptile in New Zealand\n which has a third eye on its forehead: Tuatara
For producing high frequency\n carrier wave we can use: Oscillator
What is the common name of Agaricus?: Mushroom
This non-metal conducts electricity\n by the movement of electrons: Graphite
Epic is a web browser\n made by which country?: India
The visible part of the Sun: Photosphere
The day on which the Sun’s direct\n rays cross the celestial equator: Equinox
Moths are a member of this order: Lepidoptera
By that scale, water freezes at 32 degrees: Fahrenheit
Who said, \"God does not play dice with the universe\"?: Einstein
What is a tropical cyclone called\n in the Atlantic Ocean?: Hurricane
The name for the aircraft body: Fuselage
This millionaire industrialist\n started in Cleveland: Rockefeller
The lowermost layer of the atmosphere: Troposphere
The hot desert which is covered\n with large rocks: Hamada
The surface of the continental crust: Sial
The science of making maps: Cartography
The rocky crust of the earth\n on which we live: Lithosphere
The process of wastage of glaciers: Ablation
Limestone when metamorphosed is: Marble
The most important factor for\n determining the climate of a place: Latitude
It was the first metal found out by men: Copper
What compelled the Neolithic men\n to stay in one place?: Agriculture
Greek astronomer in the ancient period: Ptolemy
This is the only animal in the world\n to have four horns: Chausingha
In what sport would one find an Albion round?: Archery
In polo, what is a period of play called?: Chukka
It follows a deuce in tennis: Advantage
In this country golf was invented: Scotland
This sport was the first\n to have a world championship: Billiards
A Turkish dish made of stuffed vegetables: Dolma
It gives peppers their heat: Capsaicin
It gives plants their green color: Chlorophyll
It is India’s national fruit: Mango
This instrument is known as the \"thumb piano\": Kalimba
This instrument is thought to be\n closest to the human voice: Violin
A term that means \"very loud\": Fortissimo
What kind of weapon is a falchion?: Sword
He fell in love with his own reflection: Narcissus
In mythology, this nymph\n was turned into a laurel bush: Daphne
A female deer: Doe
It contains juniper as a flavour: Gin
This country is famous for moussaka: Greece
This bird has the largest wing span: Albatross
What does a cooper make?: Barrel
Which black and white bird\n is usually accused of stealing?: Magpie
He wrote The Unfinished Symphony: Schubert
What is kelp?: Seaweed
A legendary chief of the Onondaga tribe: Hiawatha
Greek word for 'easy death': Euthanasia
What type of song is a doxology?: Hymn
The legendary son\n of British king Luther Pendragon: Arthur
It is measured in Hertz: Frequency
A line running through places\n of equal pressure: Isobar
From this creature\n sepia was originally obtained: Cuttlefish
A surveyor use to measure\n horizontal and vertical angles: Theodolite
It is the common name for the tree\n known as the arbutus: Strawberry
The Carthaginian general who defeated\n the Romans at the Battle of Cannae: Hannibal
